_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Boar's Head Provisions Co. Inc. operates a meat processing plant located at 2230 Wyatts Mill Rd. Jarratt, Virginia, the plant employs 600 production personnel distributed on three shifts. The facility uses Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3) in the refrigeration system as a heat transfer media. Most of the facility is cooled to 35 to 40 degrees in order to preserve the meat products and food items. The ammonia refrigeration system is computer controlled and the facility is manned 24 hours a day 7 days a week. The materials used in the covered process are of the highest standards available to the industry and the Boar's Head Management and Engineering team maintains that the contractors used to install or maintain the refrigeration system meet the highest qualifications dictated by the P.S.M. standard. The facility has ammonia detectors located in the refrigeration equipment rooms as well as the main production areas. The facility is operated under the P.S.M. standard and complies with all O.S.H.A. and federal as well as state and local codes and ordinances.

 PROCESS TECHINICAL DESCRIPTION:
The refrigeration system operates as a two-stage ammonia recirculation system @ 4:1recirculation rate. Defrost is achieved by utilizing hot gas taken directly from the compressor discharge header. 
In the compressor room there are a total of (7) seven Frick screw compressors: (2) (#1&2) RWB-40, (1) one (#3) RWB-54, (1) one (#4) RWBII-134, (2) (#5&6) RWBII-177 and one (#7) RWBII-222. Under normal operation conditions (1) one (#1) RWB-40 operates as a booster compressor and maintains a -22 (2psig) in the (#1) 42"x12' vertical recirculator. This accumulator is dedicated to the -20F/-10F freezer, the Howe ice makers and the Polar Massager glycol chiller units. The booster's discharge gas flows into the intercooler below the liquid ammonia level where the gas is desuperheated. The (6) six other screw compressors operate as high stage compressors maintaining a +12F (25psig) temperature in both the

(#2) 42"x12' recirculator and the (#3) 60"x11' recirculator as well as the (#4) 42"x11' recirculator. These three vessels are dedicated to the cooler and production area loads throughout the plant.
The (#2) compressor and the (#4) compressor are cross connected to the freezer suction and are able to swing to either duty as required.
The high stage compressors discharge gas into the refrigerant discharge piping header through which it enters the (1) Frick AFC-350, (1) Imeco XLPH-365, (1) Evapco PMCA-585 and two (2) Imeco XLP-XL-710 evaporative condensers. In the condensers the ammonia gas is cooled and condensed into a liquid state (95F) and flows into the 60"x 18' horizontal high pressure receiver located under the condensers. The liquid leaves the receiver to feed the (4) four recirculators and the intercooler as well as cooling for the seven Frick compressors.
Throught the ammonia refrigeration system and the related piping there are 33,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. 
                                                                                                             
 CONTINGENCY PLAN:
If an associate or supervisor/manager identifies an emergency situation they must contact the nearest supervisor or manager of the area. He/she will investigate the problem and decide if the Emergency Response Plan needs to be activated. The supervisor/manager will then notify the guardhouse of the situation and give the pre-determined codes. Depending on the severity of the situation the guard on duty will notify the plant manager and he will at this time decide what type of evacuation should take place (total or partial). When the complexity so indicates he will notify the Boar's Head HAZMAT team and begin the emergency response system. (SEE THE ATTACHED INTEGRATED CONTINGENCY PLAN "THE ONE PLAN" FOR DETAILS)

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEA

SE SCENARIOS:
#1. Worst case scenario, leak at the high pressure receiver due to mechanical damage of the piping during the ammonia unloading process. This particular scenario was selected because this operation involves the connecting and disconnecting of hoses to the vessel, we feel that there is an element of mistakes because of the human factor involved in this procedure, the high pressure receiver will only hold 9000 pounds of ammonia , we allowed an additional 1000 pounds for the connected piping and hoses.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Boar's Head maintains that we will utilize the best standards available to the ammonia refrigeration industry, we are members of the IIAR and stay up to date on the latest technology that is used in our process.  (see attached ammonia refrigeration guidlines for details)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Boar's Head management team recognizes that safety and safety training are paramount to a environment of productivity and well being of the associates in our facility as well as the surrounding community, we have on staff a full time safety coordinator and nurses on all production shifts, we routinely train all of the associates on process safety as well as lockout tagout, hazcom and food safety.
The refrigeration system is adding ammonia detectors in all production areas to enhance the safety of the system, as upgrades become available Boar's Head will purchase new equipment and software for the ammonia refrigeration system. The Boar's Head management team at the Jarratt Va. facility will continue to improve the safety and reliability of the ammonia refrigeration system through maintaining the equipment in the best manner availabl

e to our industry and continous monitoring of the PSM system. The training that we use for the refrigeration operators/mechanics is comprised of hands on, books and computer assisted testing. We not only train the operators/ mechanics on the refrigeration system but also use electrical and mechanical skills training as well.

SECTION I - PLAN INTRODUCTION ELEMENTS

I. PURPOSE:  Boar's Head Provisions is a further processor of cut meats.  Due to the required temperatures that need to be maintained on a consistent basis, Boar's Head provision uses Anhydrous Ammonia as a refrigerant.  If there is a release of Anhydrous Ammonia, any other hazardous chemical or oil, this plan will eliminate confusion for facility HAZMAT personnel.  The guidance is designed to yield a highly functional document for use in varied emergency situations and establish coordination between facility HAZMAT personnel and local, state and federal emergency response personnel.

II. SCOPE:    This Integrated Contingency Plan will be used by Boar's Head Provision's to prepare Emergency Response Plans for responding to releases of highly hazardous substances.  The intent is to provide a mechanism for consolidating multiple plans that Boar's Head my have to comply with into one functional Emergency Response Plan or Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP).  The Integrated Contingency Plan is also commonly referred to as the "One Plan".

PROCEDURES FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF OBJECTIVES AND                       
       PIORITIES FOR RESPONSE

1. Immediate goals/tactical planning:

a. The immediate goal in specific incident is assuring the safety and health of BH employees and rendering aid to those in need. It is also the goal of the BH HAZMAT team to control the situation and clear up the contaminated area before it harms the environment and the well being of the Jarratt/Purdy communities. 
	         
2. Mitigating actions

a. Depending on the situation at hand, it is the total responsibility of the     HAZMAT team to take full control of the incident and recover any hazardous material that may be detrimental to the public and the surrounding environment.

b. The BH HAZMAT team will use the equipment provided for containment recovery and team safety.  They will use absorbent material to recover any lost contaminant and dispose of it in accordance to federal, state and local laws in order to prevent any contamination of the surrounding environment.  The BH HAZMAT team will have a decontamination area after the incident is under control to wash down any contaminated equipment.  Measures will be taken to dispose of decon material in accordance to Federal, State and Local laws.


c. Mitigating actions must be tailored to the type of hazard present.  If there is an oil or a chemical spill, the following steps shall be taken:

* Assessment of the situation by the incident commander and the Safety & Health Manager using the appropriate resources.
* Action must be taken to direct flow away from storm drains and tributaries.  It is a goal of BH HAZMAT team personnel to prevent any contamination to the surrounding environment.
* If there is a chemical spill involving two or more highly reactive chemicals, extreme care should be taken in order to ensure safety of BH HAZMAT team personnel.
* If the situation becomes immediately dangerous to life and health, the situation shall be aborted.

SECTION II - CORE PLAN ELEMENTS

H. DISCOVERY:  This section addresses the initial action the persons discovering an incident will take to assess the problem at hand and access the response system.

A. If an associate or manager/supervisor identifies an emergency situation, they must contact the nearest supervisor or manager in the area.  He or she will give the location and a brief description of the emergency problem.  The Supervisor or Manager will investigate the reported emergency problem and will determine if the Integrated Contingency Plan needs to be activated.  The Supervisor or Manager will then notify the guardhouse of the situation and give the predetermined codes.  Depending on the situation and its s

everity, the guard on duty will notify the Plant Manager.  The Plant Manager will make the decision on what type of evacuation should take place (total or partial).  When complexity so indicates, the HAZMAT team will be notified.

II. INITIAL RESPONSE:

A. PROCEDURES FOR INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS:

1. Once the severity of the situation is determined, the HAZMAT team shall be notified.  The Safety Officer will contact the Incident Commander and the Refrigeration Supervisor and a determination will be made on whether the emergency response management system needs to be established.

2. The guardhouse will contact the proper outside emergency services.  These organizations include:

THE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN

EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM:

1. The Plant Manager has the responsibility and authority for the organization, direction and coordination of all activities, including assistance by outside parties, to cope with chemical release emergencies or oil spills that may occur.

2. The readily available HAZMAT technician will assume incident command and assign safety, medical, entry team, decon and backup team officers until relieved by higher authority.  The Incident Commander and Safety Officer will establish the incident command center in the guard shack or Maintenance office as applicable.

3. The Incident Commander will determine actions to be taken and assist or direct, as required, responding emergency personnel, Security, Safety, Medical, Entry, Backup and Maintenance.  It shall be noted here that the Maintenance supervisor is on the HAZMAT team and will be a critical contact for the Incident Commander.


4. The Safety Officer will assist the Incident commander in his duties and will also be Liaison officer.  His responsibilities will include the following:

a. Will not authorize entry into the hot zone until Decon is set up.

b. Will monitor all communications of emergency responders in the hot zone.

c. Has the authority to terminate response activities if proper safety practices are not followed.

d. Will measure and record vital signs.  Any responders that may have high vital signs will be asked not to suit up but assist with incident command.  This particular individual may even be assigned Decon officer.

e. Will report injuries to the ICC and notify supporting emergency medical services when directed.

f. Will measure and record vital signs of emergency responders after return form the hot zone and initiate further monitoring or treatment as necessary

g. Can downgrade the level of protection based on Sensidyne pump readings in the hot zone.  

5. The Plant Manager or other designated individual will act as the public information officer.

He/she will be responsible for contact with the press and civil authorities.  He will be responsible for all release information.  All critical information shall be given to him in the press release form.

B. ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INCIDENT COMMAND CENTER:
 
1. Upon initial notification by Supervisors other Emergency Response personnel of a suspected chemical release, the Incident Commander, Safety Officer and other Emergency Response Officers will form the Incident Command Center in accordance to the direction of the wind.


2. Upon formation of the ICC, the Incident Commander will dispatch two members of the Emergency Response Team to the release area with Level A hazardous response equipment:

a. Totally Encapsulated Suit

b. Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA)

c. Sensidyne pump and ammonia detection tubes or appropriate detection tubes.

d. Radio communications ability.

C. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES: 

1. Upon notification that a suspected release has occurred, the Incident Commander will perform the following tasks:

a. Establish the Incident Command Center.

b. Restrict movement of all personnel throughout the area surrounding the hot zone.

c. Identify the hot, warm and safe zones.

d. Dispatch the Emergency Responders to the area for investigation.
 
e. Establish a decontamination area.

f. Instruct Responding personnel to cut the flow of hazardous chemicals to the hot zone.  The Refrigeration Supervisor or Lead Person will be a critical contact for this procedure.

g. Instruct Responding personnel to turn off all electrical power feeding the hot zone if necessary.  The Maintenance Supervisor will be a critical contact for this procedure.  


h. Entry Team and Backup team will suit up and report time on air.

* Sensidyne pump readings will be taken at the perimeter of the hot zone, midpoint and in the release area at a minimum.  The ICC should be notified of each reading by radio.

* Make an assessment of the

release area and notify the ICC of damage and the scope of the release.  They shall also inform the ICC if the release is local or an area release.  A localized release is a release that is confined to problem area.  An area release is a release that has spread to surrounding areas other than the problem area.

* Report findings to the ICC or return to the entry point for further instructions.

* The entry team will make necessary repairs or return to the entry point for necessary tools.

* The entry team will re-enter the hot zone and make the necessary repairs.  If the entry team has exhausted their oxygen cylinders to the point that re-entry could endanger their livelihood, then the backup team will enter the established hot zone.

* If the backup team is not required to enter the hot zone, they will remain on stand by at the entrance to the hot zone and assist the entry team in the case of an emergency.

i. Other Emergency responders will standby at the ICC and will receive instructions from the Incident Commander.

j. If the release is of major proportions and uncontrollable as determined by the Incident Commander and Safety Officer, only the following steps will be taken:

* Cut the flow of the chemical to the area if this procedure has not yet been already performed.
* Cut the power to the area.
* Evacuate all personnel from the area.
* Contact the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality.
* Contact the EPA national response hotline.


D. RESPONSE DURING NIGHTS OR WEEKENDS:

1. The refrigeration mechanic on duty or the senior-trained management employee will assume Incident Command until relieved by a higher authority.  If complexity so indicates, then the security guard on duty shall refer to Section II.A.3.a above.

E. ESTABLISHMENT OF A DECONTAMINATION STATION:

1. All persons entering the hot zone will be decontaminated upon re-entering the warm zone.  This will be done utilizing the procedures listed below.  The decontamin

ation area will be located immediately outside and upwind from the hot zone.

a. Decontamination team will wear proper personal protective equipment.

2. Decontamination team will wash down all persons exiting the hot zone using medium pressure, warm water using a minimum of the following three stations:

a. Station 1: Employee will step into a footbath and follow instructions of the decontamination team.  The first step is a dry brush down to remove gross contamination and an inspection of the employees' protective suit.  Employee will be asked about air supply or other problem.  Decontamination team will use a mild detergent and water solution to wash off the surface of the suit.

b. Employee will step into the second footbath where his suit will be rinsed off. 

c. Employee will enter the third station where his protective gear will be pealed off.  The respirator will be the final item of gear removed.

d. Vital signs of the employee will be monitored and further medical monitoring may be recommended.

3. Emergency decontamination will consist of removal of gross contamination and washing the injured employee to remove contamination to a point where it is safe to begin emergency medical treatment.  Further decontamination will be done as possible.  

4. The ICC will be debriefed and any necessary cleanup will begin.



F. PROCEDURES FOR PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT OF THE SITUATION:

1. After the initial phase of the emergency response system has been established, the safety officer and the incident commander will work hand in hand in assessing the situation using MSDS books, and other available resources.  The Safety Officer and Incident Commander will then identify the hazards involved, the magnitude of the problem and resources threatened.  Based on this information, he will make the determination and place a priority on the situation and make the determination if HAZMAT personnel should continue emergency operations or abort operations.

 H.

f there is an anhydrous ammonia release, the following steps and actions shall be taken:

* Assessment of the situation by the incident commander and the safety officer using the appropriate resources.  These resources shall include the use of the Sensidyne pump, detection tubes and the Passport Monitor.
* Identification of all forms of resources that will be needed.
* Action should be taken by the refrigeration mechanic on duty to close all valves that may feed the affected area after contacting the Refrigeration Supervisor or Utilities Manager.  If procedure has not been completed, then the entry team shall take control of the situation and close all valves leading to the affected area.
* Action must be taken to direct flow away from storm drains and tributaries.  It is a goal of BH HAZMAT team personnel to prevent any contamination to the surrounding environment.

3. Identification of resources required for response

a. Depending on the incident, different measures will be taken.  All resources needed for response to any type of incident will be available.  In the event the incident cannot be prioritized and the resources required for response cannot be identified, air monitoring shall be performed to determine oxygen levels in an emergency situation.  Based on this monitoring, a decision can be made on the resources needed.


1. PROCEDURES FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF TACTICAL PLAN

1. The guardhouse will acknowledge the incoming call from a supervisor or manager and alert them to the situation. 

2. The guardhouse will then contact the plant manager so determination can be made on the evacuation measures.

3. Once the evacuation order is given and evacuation is complete, maintenance personnel will remain behind to monitor essential plant operations.  The severity of the situation will determine whether all these actions will be carried out.  Maintenance personnel will not be asked to enter an atmosphere or situation that may be immediately dangerous

to life and health without donning the proper equipment.

4. Dependent upon the severity of the situation, HAZMAT team personnel will be notified.

5. Upon arrival of HAZMAT team personnel, an incident command post will assemble in accordance to the direction of the windsocks.
  
6. An entry team and backup team will be established.

7. The Incident Commander and Safety Officer will work hand in hand in assessing the situation and using the appropriate resources to determine the priority of the situation.  Upon entering, all HAZMAT personnel will use the "buddy system" to ensure each other's safety.

8. Upon identification and prioritizing of the situation, the entry team shall use the appropriate resources to contain the affected area and control the incident.

9. Once the situation has been controlled and contained, cleanup procedures shall follow.  All absorbent material shall be disposed of properly in accordance to federal, state and local laws.
 
10. Once cleanup is complete, all entry team personnel and their equipment will go through the decon station.



F. PROCEDURES FOR MOBILIZATION OF RESOURCES

1. All equipment and resources are stored in the Boar's Head special operations trailer.  The company truck or an appropriate vehicle will transport the trailer within an established safe zone to allow for equipment setup.  This will be the established Incident Command Post.

III. SUSTAINED ACTIONS

A. The transition from the initial emergency stage and the response stage shall be smooth.  Most incidents shall be handled by only a few individuals without an extensive response management system.  It shall be the responsibility of security to maintain crowd and press control. There shall not be any interference with BH HAZMAT operations.

IV. INCIDENT TERMINATION AND FOLLOW UP

A. The incident commander and safety officer shall work hand in hand to terminate the response if complexity indicates.  If the incident is under control, then pr

oper cleanup procedures shall be implemented in response to federal, local and state laws.

B. In the event the incident worsens and it may be immediately dangerous to life and health of the HAZMAT team personnel, the Incident Commander and Safety Officer shall be able to recognize this situation and abort operations. 

C. Follow up actions will be taken after termination of the operation.  These actions shall include:

1. Incident Investigation to determine what caused the accident and the contributing factors leading up to the incident.

2. A written response critique on the total response which shall include but not limited to the following: wind direction, identification of chemicals involved, the time it took for setup of operations and dressing out, how many team members made entry, how long it took them to control the situation, how long each member was in the hot zone and how long it took for cleanup operations and decon.



3. A review of the response plan to help make the determination on what areas need improvement, equipment inadequacies and purchases that need to be made what resources were used and if there were any problems complying with Federal, State and local laws.

4. A follow up report shall be written and shall address the above criteria.  The appropriate annexes will be referenced.

The supervisor or manager will call the guardhouse (ext. 5139 or 5140) and will give their name and predetermined codes. ANNEX 3. RESPONSE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM

A. GENERAL - TEAM MEMBER RESPONSIBILITIES

a. Assess incident priorities
b. Determines strategic goals and tactical objectives

b. Identify chemical and the incompatibilities.
c. Monitor Wind Direction.

3. Entry Team

a. Defensive operations.
b. Plugging and patching.

4. Entry Team (Back up)

a. Assist the initial entry team
b. Offensive operations

d. Controlling the spill and stopping release.


B.

UNIFIED COMMAND

1. In the event there is a need for help form local authorities, the proper steps shall be taken to inform them on how far along the response efforts have proceeded.  The incident commander shall relay the following information:

a. Chemical identity and the hazards associated with it.

b. Total response time at that moment.

c. The actual cause of the incident.

d. The number of BH HAZMAT team personnel in the hot zone.

e. The direction of the wind.

f. What equipment is available.

g. And the exasperated resources.

* Upon recieval of this information, the responding service shall assist BH HAZMAT personnel in their attempt to control the situation.  The Jarratt Volunteer Fire Department will assist BH security personnel on securing the scene.  They will assist in the HAZMAT response if needed.

C. COMMAND 

1. The Facility Incident Commander will be established based on the most senior-trained HAZMAT technician until released by a higher authority.

2. The incident commander has the responsibility to assess incident priorities and determine strategic goals and tactical objectives to take control of any situations.  He develops command structure to meet the needs of the incident and determines what resources are needed.  The Incident Commander coordinates all activities.  The Plant Manager has overall authority to release information to the public and press.  He must receive a formal copy of all information from the Incident Commander and the established Safety Officer.

3. Command post shall be designated in accordance to the direction of the wind.


B. INFORMATION (internal and external communication)

1. Facility employees will be informed of the situation when plant evacuation has occurred.  They will not be given detailed information concerning the emergency.  BH does not want any false information circulating among the general public and the press.

2. Local and state authorities will notify the public in t

he event the emergency situation is severe enough where this procedure is deemed necessary.

3. The Plant Manager or his designee will have the authority in addressing the press and coordination with the news media.  In case of fatalities, for confidential reasons, names of victims will not be disclosed until family members of the victim have been notified and verify release of this information.

C. SAFETY

1. In the event of an emergency, the incident commander and safety officer shall assess the scene to determine chemical identification and any possible incapabilities of the surrounding environment that may cause a more severe situation.  Upon this assessment and based on the information provided, the incident commander shall place a priority on the situation.  If the situation is deemed too severe than BH HAZMAT team personnel will be called upon to act.

2. HAZMAT members will not be permitted to enter the contaminated areas without using the buddy system.  The buddy system means organizing employees into work groups in such a manner that each member is observed by one of the members on the HAZMAT team.  Failure to use the buddy system could be costly.  The purpose of the buddy system is to provide rapid assistance to employees in the event of an emergency.

3. Decontamination setup

a. This is the station where removal of hazardous substances from HAZMAT personnel is performed.  All equipment and tools must pass through the decon station.  The purpose of decon is to preclude the occurrence of any foreseeable adverse health effects.


4. A Health Hazard means a chemical, mixture of chemicals or a pathogen for which there is statistically significant evidence based on at least one study conducted in accordance with established scientific principles that acute or chronic health effects may occur in exposed team members.

5. The hot zone shall be heavily monitored upon entrance by HAZMAT team personnel until the incident is deemed to be a highly h

azardous situation and endangers personnel.  When the determination is made that response are to risky, responding personnel will abort operations

6. Facility personnel will be able to respond to an emergency alarm and will be provided with an easily accessible evacuation route.  Medically trained personnel will be available to render aid to those associates who may need it.  An outside emergency medical service authority will be on scene as well.  In the event that the priority of the emergency situation presents a greater danger, all plant personnel will be asked to leave BH property for their own personal safety.

D. STAFF MOBILIZATION - LIASON

1. In the event of an emergency situation, there may be a need for outside assistance.  BH HAZMAT team and the Jarratt Volunteer Fire Department will work together depending on the severity of the situation.  Upon arrival to the scene, the Jarratt Fire Department will be briefed on the situation at hand, the hazards that are being dealt with, the dangers these hazards pose to human life, what actions and offensive/defensive moves that have been tried, physical data concerning the environment and how long the situation has been combated.  The Fire Department will be told what actions need to be taken and will be made aware of what resources are still available.  They will be informed on what consist of the hot, warm and cold zone.  The goal here is to establish a unified command so the well being of the general public and the environment is not threatened.

E. OPERATIONS

1. Operational Response Objectives

a. Depending on the emergency situation on hand (ammonia release, chemical or oil spill) it will be the universal goal of BH HAZMAT team personnel to obtain complete and total control of the situation.  This may or may not require the need for assistance from outside sources.


2. Discharge or Release Control

a. BH HAZMAT team personnel will use the resources on hand to contain the chemical spill, oil

spill or ammonia release.  This includes the use of absorbent material and diking procedures to prevent contamination in the surrounding environment.

b. BH HAZMAT team personnel shall consist of refrigeration technicians knowledgeable of all workstations and their locations.  This is critical when closing off valves and pipes that affect the immediate area.  The primary goal here is to isolate the affected area.

3. Assessment and monitoring

a. The safety officer and the Incident Commander will do assessment and monitoring on a continual basis throughout the response.  The entry team will enter the hot zone and monitor the oxygen levels and ammonia levels.  With the use of ammonia detection tubes, a determination shall be made on the PPM concentration.  This information will be communicated to the incident commander and safety officer if the response shall be terminated.
                             
4. Containment

a. As before mentioned, BH HAZMAT team personnel will work hand in hand to contain or dike any release or spill and prevent it form being discharged or released into storm drains or tributaries draining from Boar's Head Property.

5. Recovery

a. It will be a primary goal of BH HAZMAT personnel to recover as much contaminant as possible.

6. Decontamination

a. All persons entering the hot zone will be decontaminated upon re-entering the warm zone.  This will be done utilizing the procedures listed below.  The decon area will be located immediately outside and upwind from the hot zone.

b. The decon team will wear proper personal protective equipment.


c. The decon team will wash down all persons entering the hot zone using medium, warm water.

d. Emergency decontamination will consist of removal of gross contamination and washing the injured employee to remove contamination.  The employee will be moved to an area where it is safe to begin emergency medical treatment.  Further decontamination will be done as soon as possible.

e. The Incident command center will be debriefed and any necessary cleanup will begin.

7. Non responder medical needs (plant associates)

a. The plant medically trained employees shall render medical attention and responding Emergency Medical Services if needed for those individuals that are not members of the HAZMAT team. 

F. PLANNING

1. Process Hazard Analysis shall be conducted every 5 years or more frequently when the Management of Change dictates.  

G. PROTECTION

1. All equipment, components and materials used in the system will be designed and manufactured for ammonia refrigeration service, will comply with ASME code B31.5-1992 and will meet system pressure and temperature requirements.

a. Protective booming shall be used when applicable, in those areas that may have a potential of contaminating the surrounding environment.

b. In the event there is a release of anhydrous ammonia and it had the potential to harm the surrounding communities, measures would be taken on notifying those individuals with the assistance of local authorities and emergency services.  The Virginia Department of Environmental quality will be contacted at (804) 527 - 5000 for assistance.  The Greensville county sheriff's office will be contacted at 911.  It shall be noted here that Boar's Head Provisions is located in an isolated area away from any vulnerable receptors.


c. Coordination with the Virginia Department of Environmental quality and other appropriate organizations for monitoring, sampling and wildlife recovery/rehabilitation.

2. Planning scenarios - In accordance to the Clean Air Act (CAA) and Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (OPA), planning scenarios shall be developed for certain types and sizes of releases.

a. There is an above ground used oil storage tank that has a capacity of 8,000 gallons.  This tank is bermed by a 12' x 12' x 4.5' berm wall.  The wall should be adequate to contain any size spill.  The spill would be reported to the EPA an

d disposal shall be in accordance to local, federal and state laws.

b. Due to circumstances that may arise, the bermed wall may prove to be inadequate.  If this is the case, the contaminated area shall be diked and absorbent hydrocarbon pellets shall be scattered on the affected area.  These pallets are biodegradable.

c. If the spill is in excess of 100 gallons or more, then the spill shall be reported to the EPA and the VDEQ.  Response and disposal shall be in accordance to local, federal and state laws.

* Above ground #2 fuel oil tank (diesel fuel)

a. There is an above ground #2 fuel oil tank with a capacity of 15,000 gallons.  This tank is bermed by a 30' x 5' x 3.5' berm wall.  The wall should be adequate to contain any size spill.  The spill would be reported to the EPA and disposal shall be in accordance to local, federal and state laws.

b. Due to circumstances that may arise, the berm wall may prove to be inadequate.  If this is the case, then the contaminated area shall be diked and absorbent material shall be put down to stop any storm drain contamination.  Absorbent hydrocarbon pellets shall be place down to help contain and stop the flow of the spill.  As stated above, these hydrocarbon pellets are biodegradable.

c. If the spill is in excess of 100 gallons or more, then the spill shall be reported to the EPA and the VDEQ.  Response and disposal shall be in accordance to local, federal and state laws.


* Storage drums

a. There are two 55-gallon storage drum areas, each containing chemicals, used oil or empty barrels.  The chemical storage areas also contain 330-gallon totes.  Most of the storage drums have been eliminated and the chemicals and oils are stored in bulk containers.  This procedure is in accordance to Boar's Head's established spill prevention control and countermeasure plan.

b. Due to circumstances that may arise, a spill may occur.  In the event of the spill, responding personnel shall use absorbent material to co

ntain the situation.  If the spill is in excess of 100 gallons or more (based on the chemical), then the spill shall be reported to the EPA and the VDEQ (Virginia Department of Environmental Quality).  Preventive measures shall be taken to deter the spill away from storm drains and tributaries.

* Ammonia Releases

a. Due to the circumstances that may arise, there may be an ammonia release.  The release may be (minor) tolerable or major (intolerable).  A minor release is a release of anhydrous ammonia in concentrations less than 50 ppm.  If a release is minor, the supervisor will be notified and the plant manager will be notified.  Refrigeration technicians shall respond to the situation and take control after contacting the refrigeration supervisor.  If a release is termed a major release, the above steps shall be taken, plant evacuation will occur and the HAZMAT team will be called upon.  A major release would be a release in excess of 50 ppm and require the Incident Command System be formed.

b. If the release is in excess of 100 lbs. or more, then the EPA and VDEQ (Virginia Department of Environmental Quality) shall be notified.  The local fire department will be called upon for scene security and assistance if needed.

c. Responding HAZMAT personnel will use the available HAZMAT equipment located in the special operations trailer.


d. If the release is a minor release, it will be just that until the concentrations exceed 50ppm.  In some situations, the responding refrigeration technician may use preventive measures that may raise the concentration levels.  However, the system is isolated and the problem is controlled.  This would not be deemed a HAZMAT response situation.  The HAZMAT team will be on standby if needed.  Plant personnel other than the responding personnel will not be permitted in the affected area.  If the preventive measure does cause the ammonia levels to rise, then the refrigeration personnel must notify responding personnel of the

increase.
 
H. COORDINATION WITH NATURAL RESOURCES TRUSTEES

1. VDEQ - The Virginia Department of Environmental Quality will be contacted for assistance.  Natural Resource Trustees will do a natural resource drainage assessment (NRDA) if deemed necessary.

I. WASTE MANAGEMENT

1. Disposal of contaminated materials shall be in accordance with federal, state and local requirements.  The Virginia Department of Environmental Quality will be a key contact if assistance is need.

J. LOGISTICS

1. Medical needs of responders:

a. There will be a first aid kit on hand at the incident command center.

b. The Safety & Health Manager is a certified EMT-B and can help with an emergency if needed.

c. There will be Emergency Medical Services on standby if needed.

d. If a situation does arise, the injured or overexerted responder will be taken out of the hot zone, through the decon station and into the cold zone so medical attention can be rendered.


K. SITE SECURITY

1. Due to the arising circumstances and the situation on hand, scene security must be maintained.  The traffic gate must be clear for responding vehicles.  This area will be maintained by on site security officer.

2. The Jarratt Volunteer Fire Department will respond accordingly and will assist in maintaining scene security. 

L. PERSONNEL SUPPORT

1. If complexity of the situation so dictates, meals will be provided for BH HAZMAT team personnel.  It shall be noted here that BH HAZMAT team personnel will combat a situation that can be controlled.  If the situation is uncontrollable, BH HAZMAT team personnel will be informed to abort operations or not to respond.

M. EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE AND SUPPORT

1. If complexity of the situation so dictates and there is a need for additional equipment and personnel support, the Jarratt Volunteer Fire Department will assist in the situation.

2. The HAZMAT equipment will be inspected on a regular basis so any defects can be detected.  Thi

s will ensure that all air bottles are fully charged.

ANNEX 7.  PREVENTION 

A. Boar's Head Provisions has established prevention-based requirements in accordance to the established Boar's Head Process Safety Management manual and Standard Operating Procedures.  The Mechanical Integrity portion of the Process Safety Management manual addresses preventive maintenance checklist for ammonia compressors, evaporative condensers, air-cooling evaporators, pressure vessels and piping and valve systems. These checklists are filled out monthly and are in place to detect any weaknesses or malfunctions in the ammonia system.
